subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etym}}
{{liushu|ic}} : A needle {{zh-l|*䇂}} (abbreviated to {{zh-l|*立}}) going through a slave's eye. In ancient China, slaves were blinded. Compare {{zh-l|*民}}.

It is also possible that it is a {{Han compound|立|重|c1=s|c2=p|ls=psc|nocap=y}}. The bottom component is unrelated to {{zh-l|*里}}.

Original meaning was “boy servant”.

subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
; “child; servant boy; virgin; bare”
: {{zh-ref|Löffler (1966)}} compares it to {{cog|tbq-kuk}} {{m|und|dong||boy}}; see also {{w|Rengmitca}} {{m|und||'''tong'''-kléng'|boy}}, Areng {{m|und||'''thon'''-dén|boy}} ({{zh-ref|Löffler, 1960}}). <!-- Schuessler calls it "Khami", but Löffler did not specific this. --> {{zh-ref|Schuessler (2007)}} also compares it to {{cog|hmx}}: {{cog|mww|tub||son}}, {{cog|ium|dorn||son}}.
; “shaman”
: {{zh-ref|Norman and Mei (1976)}} proposed that the Min Chinese word for “shaman” (*''-dəŋ<sup>A</sup>''), written as {{lang|zh|童}}, is from an Austroasiatic substratum, cognate with {{cog|vi|đồng}}, {{cog|mnw|ဒံၚ်|tr=tòŋ||to dance while under daemonic possession; to proceed by leaps}}, {{m|mnw|ဒေါၚ်|tr=tòŋ||shaman called in to organise ''kəlok'' dances}}. This is rebutted in {{zh-ref|Sagart (2008)}}, who cited the wide distribution of the sense “magician; sorcerer” in Chinese and the secondary meaning of {{lang|zh|童}} as “servant; messenger”, describing the resemblance between the Min and Austroasiatic terms as “undoubtedly fortuitous”.
